title: 'Mistakes made': Optus bosses admit failures in fatal triple-zero outage
text:
The chairman and CEO of embattled telco Optus have been grilled at a Senate inquiry into the catastrophic triple-zero failure that left three people dead.

Human error during a firewall upgrade in September led to an outage in multiple states and territories, which led to customers being unable to call the emergency line.

Speaking at a Senate inquiry today, Optus CEO Stephen Rue admitted the mistakes made by the telco during and immediately after the outage.

Stephen Rue admitted "there were mistakes made" by the company during and after the outage. (Alex Ellinghausen)

"There is no doubt that the timeline shows there were delays, there were mistakes made," he said.

"The tragic deaths of people during this outage stay with us as individuals and as a company as we investigate the incident.

"I fully accept there are aspects to the way events unfolded and how they were communicated over September 18 and 19 that we should have handled better."

Rue said correct steps and procedures were not followed after the company became aware of the outage and admitted that despite the offshore call centre believing the network hadn't failed, the issue should have been escalated.

"This was a unique situation whereby the call centre people believed the network was not failing, but they should have escalated those calls," Rue said.

"The initial mistake, a human error, occurred when the wrong process plan was selected for a routine firewall upgrade.

"The selected plan did not divert traffic before locking equipment inside the exchange that routes triple-zero calls.

"This error was not detected because control steps were not followed and alarms were not acted on at the time."

READ MORE: ﻿ Former prince Andrew to lose final military title

Optus CEO Stephen Rue speaks to the media in the days after the outage. The company has been criticised for being slow to report how many people were impacted by the outage. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

Rue insisted this was "an explanation, not an excuse".

He also insisted the company had not been misleading in its delay in confirming how many calls were impacted in the outage.

"I wouldn't characterise it as misleading, it was information as we knew it at the time," he said.

"Sadly, it turned out to be different, we accept that."

READ MORE: ﻿ Shock CCTV shows moment man is snatched off the street in Sydney

The outage is one of many high-profile incidents to hit the company in recent years. (Getty)

The fallout has been disastrous for Optus, with the triple-zero failure the latest in a long line of incidents and issues at the company over the last three years.

Rue, who came into the company in 2023 after previous CEO Kelly Rosmarin resigned in the wake of a nationwide outage, is also under increased pressure to keep his job.

Two Optus executives have already announced their departure,﻿ but Rue received an endorsement from Optus chairman John Arthur.

"There were I think 10 failures here, 10 failures. And if you're asking me whether I am alarmed at that, I can assure you I am," he said.

"However, this man was brought into this company to make sure we became a company that didn't have 10 failures like that.

"Now that's his job, and I'm expecting him to finish it."

READ MORE: ﻿ The concerning factor believed to be behind surging house prices

Optus chairman John Arthur insisted Stephen Rue was the right man for the role of CEO. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Rue said it was not the right time for him to step away from the company.

"I firmly believe that another change of leader at this time is not what Optus needs, or what our customers need," he said.

Optus has been criticised for having critical infrastructure and call centres located offshore, and Rue said the company had made changes as a result of the triple-zero failure.

"We will take back calls that relate to triple-zero calls and relate to vulnerable customers… and ensure that they are dealt with onshore in Australia. And we're in the process of doing exactly that," he said.

"Our contact centre procedures have been overhauled, including a mandatory escalation process for any customer reports of triple-zero issues."

title: The concerning factor believed to be behind surging house prices
text:
A﻿head of tomorrow's interest rates decision by the Reserve Bank of Australia, the impact of the bank of mum and dad on home prices continues to stir debate.

The cash rate is hotly tipped to remain on hold at 3.60 per cent when the RBA hands down its decision at 2.30pm tomorrow, leaving hard-pressed mortgage holders disappointed.

The forecast was supported by a survey of economic experts by comparison site Finder that found 30 from 35 expected no change.

More first home buyers are relying on family financial help to get on the housing ladder. (Photo: Dion Georgopoulos / Australian Financial Review) (Dion Georgopoulos / Australian Financial Review)

But economists and analysts showed far less unity when quizzed about the effects of parents giving their children financial support to gain a foothold in the housing market.

New Finder research – based on a survey of 1006 first-home buyers – revealed 17 per cent relied on the financial help of parents or family to save their deposit, up from 11 in 2022.

That's the equivalent of almost 20,000 first home buyers a year who were lucky enough to receive financial help from their parents.

Finder head of consumer research Graham Cooke said without it, property ownership would be out of reach for many young people.

"Those who can lean on mum and dad are typically entering the market not just sooner, but in a much stronger position," he said.

But while it's giving some lucky few a leg up, ﻿nearly one in three experts canvassed by Finder believe it is also distorting the housing market.

Among them are Michael Yardney, from Metropole Property Strategists, who thinks a twin-track housing market is evolving.

"This is creating a two-tier market of the haves and have-nots, families with property equity already and others," he said.

On the other hand, Tim Reardon from the Housing Industry Association said family support is a natural part of a well functioning market.

"[Parents] are not a distortion, they are correcting the market distortion created by the severe lending restrictions imposed on first home buyers," he said.

There was also concern about the impact of the government's First Home Guarantee Scheme, which will allow ﻿all first home buyers to purchase a home with only a 5 per cent deposit instead of the usual 20 per cent.

From the 26 experts canvassed, 65 per cent think it will encourage first home buyers to take on more debt than they should.﻿

title: Breaking: Communication breakdown led to iconic ship's damage in Fremantle harbour
text:
A lack of effective communication contributed to a collision between the sail training ship Leeuwin II and a container ship in Fremantle Harbour last year that injured two crew members, a new report has found.

The investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) found one of the harbour pilots helping navigate the 333-metre long Maersk Shekou into the port failed to issue a crucial instruction as the giant vessel battled through rough seas and stormy weather, escorted by four tugboats.

Loading...

A secondary pilot, who was meant to be monitoring the ship's arrival, was distracted by taking a non-essential phone call.

The container ship, which was laden with more than 4,000 shipping containers, struck the Leeuwin, which was berthed at the quay, causing the wooden vessel's masts to collapse.

The two crew members on the Leeuwin sustained minor injuries trying to flee the ship via the gangway as the collision occurred.

The Leeuwin was struck by a container ship. (Supplied: Roel Loopers )

Meanwhile, the Maersk Shekou's stern struck the roof of the nearby WA Maritime Museum, damaging the facade.

The report found crew on the container ship's bridge "failed to adequately monitor, or challenge, the ship's turn and position in the channel".

Loading

title: Storm star undergoes surgery after multiple head knocks in Tonga clash
text:
Melbourne Storm forward Eli Katoa suffered "seizure activity" and underwent surgery overnight after a series of head clashes in Tonga's match with New Zealand on Sunday.

Katoa was allowed to play in the Pacific Championship Test despite copping a heavy knock from teammate Lehi Hopoate in the pre-game warm-up.

He then copped another high hit in the first half and passed a HIA test, before again being hit in the head in the second half.

In concerning scenes, Katoa was pictured on the sidelines receiving oxygen from medical staff while laid out on a stretcher.

Officials later confirmed he had suffered a brain bleed.

The Storm said it was in touch with Tonga's Chief Medical Officer after concerns were raised about how Katoa had been allowed to play after the pre-game collision.

"Melbourne Storm forward Eli Katoa was taken to hospital after suffering seizure activity on the bench during the second half of yesterday's Pacific Championships match between Tonga and New Zealand," a Storm statement read on Monday morning.

"Eli underwent surgery overnight and is in a stable condition being supported by his partner and mother. Storm medical staff remain in close contact with the hospital and Tonga's team Chief Medical Officer.

"The club will provide a further update as additional information becomes available."

Katoa posted an image to Instagram on Monday morning from his hospital bed, thanking everyone for their concern.

"Appreciate everyone for checking in," he wrote.

"Sorry I haven't got back to any of you guys but I really appreciate all the love."

Tonga coach Kristian Woolf said after Sunday's game that the doctors had been confident Katoa was fine following the pre-match collision with Hopoate.

"We have two very experienced doctors there, they have done the usual HIA. He has passed all that and passed it well," Woolf said.

"My job is not to question doctors.

"They were both comfortable with that and comfortable with him coming back on to the field.

"Unfortunately he copped a second hit that was quite heavy, and there has been a bit of a poor result on the back of that."

ABC/AAP

title: What time is the Melbourne Cup? How to watch and the weather forecast
text:
Rain in Melbourne is set to play a factor in Australia's most famous horse race, with Flemington Racecourse predicted to be rated a Soft 7 or Heavy 8 for Tuesday's Melbourne Cup.

Meanwhile, the pre-race favourite is attempting to complete a special feat in Australian racing while its jockey is hoping to be the second female to ever win the Melbourne Cup.

From start time to weather forecast, below are some key things to know before the 2025 Melbourne Cup.

What time is the Melbourne Cup?

Melbourne Cup Day is held on the first Tuesday of November, which is November 4 this year.

The Melbourne Cup will be the seventh race of 10 at Flemington Racecourse.

Here are the start times for the Melbourne Cup in each state and territory, including New Zealand.

3pm AEDT: Victoria, NSW, Tasmania, ACT

2:30pm ACDT: South Australia

2pm AEST: Queensland

1:30pm ACST: Northern Territory

12pm AWST: Western Australia

5pm NZDT: New Zealand

What is the weather forecast for the Melbourne Cup?

There is plenty of rain expected to fall in the lead-up to Tuesday's Melbourne Cup.

The Bureau of Meteorology forecasted between 20-40 millimetres to fall in Melbourne on Monday, with up to another 10mm on Tuesday.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

The amount of rain set to fall in Melbourne will mean Flemington Racecourse will be wet and slow on Cup Day.

Flemington is a track that can drain well, but the rain on Monday and Tuesday has track manager Liam O'Keeffe predicting the course will either be rated a Soft 7 or Heavy 8 for the Cup.

"I would think if we get 20-40mm [on Monday] we would be on a heavy track at the end of that rainfall," O'Keeffe told Racing.com on Sunday.

"If we don't get any rain on the day [Tuesday], I would be confident we would get back into the soft range.

"But if we just get continuous showers throughout the day, which is forecast, it won't get a chance to improve."

How to watch and follow the Melbourne Cup

The Nine Network has the television rights to broadcast the 2025 Melbourne Cup.

All 10 races at Flemington will be broadcast on Channel Nine, and streamed on Nine Now.

ABC Sport will have live digital coverage of Melbourne Cup day with a live blog. You can also listen to the live call of the Melbourne Cup on the radio, online, or via the ABC Listen app.

Who is the favourite to win the Melbourne Cup?

There will be a field of 24 for the Melbourne Cup.

The favourite to win the Cup is number 14, Half Yours.

Half Yours is trained by Tony and Calvin McEvoy, and will be ridden by jockey Jamie Melham.

Half Yours won the Caulfield Cup last month and is attempting to become the 13th horse to win the Melbourne-Caulfield Cup double.

Melham would be the second female jockey ever, after Michelle Payne in 2015, to win the Melbourne Cup.

title: Plan for 1,300-room worker accommodation in WA heads to final stage of approval
text:
A $500 million, 1,300-room accommodation project in South Hedland has been given the green light by the regional Development Assessment Panel (DAP), which had rejected the first application nearly a year ago.

The Parola Court development in WA's Pilbara region, which originally proposed workforce accommodation with 1,653 rooms in November last year, has since been amended significantly by the applicant, Pacific Partnerships.

Amid housing and short-term accommodation shortages, the new plan flagged 24 of the 1,311 rooms for tourism accommodation.

Development 'could have negative impacts'

Managing director at consultancy RFF Owen Hightower said the proposed development did not align with the town's planning principles.

"The town's planning framework and rules were designed to encourage these developments to happen within the planned town centre … to ensure the facility maximised external engagement with the community," Mr Hightower said.

The proposed development is 2.3 kilometres away from the town centre.

Pacific Partnerships says the development will support the growth of mining and energy industries in the area. (ABC News: Kimberley Putland)

Mr Hightower said shifting the project closer to the centre would "deliver all the aspirations of the community" in activating the town centre.

"Where it's ended up and been approved really limits the ability for that to occur at all," he said.

Mr Hightower said the community understood the need for workforce accommodation, but the development's social impact survey highlighted concerns.

"There was an overwhelming perception that this development would have negative impacts … there were references to the location being inadequate within those surveys," he said.

Port and South Hedland face ongoing short-term accommodation shortages. (ABC News: Kimberley Putland)

A 'wait and see' approach

Town of Port Hedland Commissioners Jessica Shaw and Ron Yuryevich sat on the panel and voted to approve the development.

Ms Shaw disagrees with Mr Hightower.

"When we considered all the planning principles — which you're required to as a DAP member — we determined that it was consistent and that it would be a good development for the town," she told ABC Pilbara Kimberley Mornings.

"It's a significant investment into Port Hedland.

"It will alleviate a lot of those housing issues, both for temporary workers and for permanent housing and so, yes, we did support the project."

Ron Yuryevich (left) and Jessica Shaw (right) were on the Development Assessment Panel. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

While not a condition of approval, the proponent agreed to make a voluntary contribution of $2.5 million every 10 years to the Town of Port Hedland.

Ms Shaw said she and Mr Yuryevich argued for the contributions to be a condition of approval, but they were outvoted.

The estimated lifespan of the development is 40 years, valuing the deal at $10 million.

Hedland First National Real Estate general manager Scott Lowe said the benefit of the development might be to ease housing shortages in the town.

Scott Lowe says the development could be a "net positive" for the community. (ABC News: Rachel Pupazzoni)

"Our preference would always be to see investment into permanent residential accommodation," he said.

"This facility might actually support that, in that if some of the occupants currently housed in permanent housing moved into it, then it frees up some accommodation in town for families or permanent residents to move into town.

" It's a 'wait and see' approach I guess because it could be net positive. "

Water Corporation 'confident' it can work with developer

Port Hedland's water supply constraint was raised by both Mr Hightower and Ms Shaw.

The applicant said Water Corporation had not flagged any issues with supply.

A Water Corporation spokesperson told the ABC that it was waiting for further information since providing advice last year.

"Once this is received, we are confident of being able to work with the developer to support the proposal in a staged and orderly way," the spokesperson said.

The ABC understands the development plan is expected to go before the Town of Port Hedland for approval in the coming months.

title: New York Marathon won by 0.2 seconds after classic sprint
text:
Benson Kipruto has survived a thrilling sprint finish to claim victory in the New York Marathon, winning with a time of 2 hours, 8 minutes and 9 seconds.

Kipruto ran flat out through the final 50 metres on Sunday, local time, to hold off a late fight from Alexander Mutiso, breaking the tape by less than two-tenths of a second in a photo finish.

The 2021 winner, Albert Korir, finished in third place in a time of 2:08:57.

"It was amazing. The last part was so hard," Kipruto said in a televised interview.

The crowd in Central Park were treated to a thrilling finish. (AP Photo: Yuki Iwamura)

"I was pushing so hard to make sure I win."

It was the fourth major title for Kipruto, who was in a two-man race with Mutiso at the 25-mile mark and appeared to be completely in control with 200 metres left.

He was forced to accelerate through the final straight, however, as Mutiso launched a gutsy late attack to wild cheers in Central Park.

Benson Kipruto and Alexander Mutiso were able to hug it out after their brilliant sprint. (AP Photo: Angelina Katsanis)

The race was the second elite marathon to end in a sprint finish in recent months, with Alphonce Felix Simbu claiming gold at the World Athletics Championships by just 0.003 seconds from Amanal Petro in Tokyo.

It was a good day for Kenya, which swept both the men's and women's podiums, with Hellen Obiri winning the women's race in a course-record time of 2:19:51.

Paris bronze medallist Obiri, who won in 2023, was running shoulder-to-shoulder with runner-up Sharon Lokedi (2:20:07) and enjoyed a comfortable finish after pulling away ahead of the final turn to claim her fourth major title.

Last year's winner, Sheila Chepkirui (2:20:24), was third.

"We had a very strong field," said Obiri, who pocketed an extra $US50,000 ($76,383) for breaking Margaret Okayo's 22-year-old course record of 2:22:31.

"[I told myself] let me try to do my best, let me push."

Hellen Obiri sprinted away in the closing stages to win comfortably. (AP Photo: Angelina Katsanis)

In the wheelchair division, Switzerland's Marcel Hug won a record-extending seventh title in the men's race in 1:30:16, while American Susannah Scaroni won the women's race in 1:42:10.

Kenyan two-time Olympic champion Eliud Kipchoge, the only man to break the 2-hour barrier in the marathon, finished 17th in 2:14:36.

Amid rampant speculation that New York could be his final competitive marathon, the 40-year-old Kipchoge instead announced plans to embark on a two-year mission to run seven marathons across seven continents in his "Eliud Kipchoge World Tour."

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

Speaking to Olympics.com before the race, Kipchoge said he had plans to run "for a purpose", including racing in Antarctica.

"November, and it's New York … It's a place that has been on my mind for a long time. It's time for me to go there and get a Seven Star [award for finishing all seven major marathons] before embarking on my new journey of running for other things," he said.

The Seven Star award is given to runners who have completed the marathons in Tokyo, Boston, London, Sydney, Berlin, Chicago and New York City.

Sydney was named a major for the first time this year.

The five-borough classic capped the World Marathon Majors calendar for the year, after a doping suspension for the women's world record holder rocked competitive distance running.

Kenyan Ruth Chepngetich was banned for three years late last month after admitting to anti-doping rule violations.

Reuters/ABC

title: More hikers getting stuck on popular trail as social media draws tourists
text:
A popular hiking trail in WA's Stirling Range National Park has seen a fourfold increase in the number of hikers being rescued so far this year, with rescuers saying a spike in visitors is the cause.

The Range, about 337 kilometres south-east of Perth, is a popular destination for hikers and tourists.

Official figures show more than 50,000 people summit Bluff Knoll each year, but emergency services said there had been a steady rise in numbers, precipitating a spike in those needing a rescue.

At 1,099m, Bluff Knoll is southern WA's highest peak. (Supplied)

Rescues increase

The Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) said rescue crews had been called to 12 incidents so far this year, up from the three for the same time last year.

A total of four people were rescued in 2024.

Last month, three people were airlifted or brought down by emergency services in three separate incidents.

Earlier in the year, an injured rock climber who spent more than 24 hours on the side of the bluff was winched off the peak in a massive rescue operation.

This year, a man became stuck in a more isolated part of the bluff favoured by rock climbers. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

DFES deputy commissioner operations Craig Waters said on average, 25 people from several emergency services were involved in each rescue.

He said the average rescue took up to eight hours, but complex conditions often meant some took longer.

"Severe weather can make rescues difficult, particularly on a summit like Bluff Knoll where volunteers need to hike the steep ascent with heavy equipment to get to injured or stranded people in the heat, wind or rain," he said.

"Aircraft, including the RAC Rescue helicopter, can be used to retrieve injured or stranded hikers but volatile weather means it cannot always safely carry out the rescue."

Mr Waters said the rescues were a reminder for hikers not to underestimate the state's more challenging tracks.

Gnowangerup and Albany State Emergency Services respond to rescues on the mountain. (Supplied: SES)

More people on the bluff

Gnowangerup SES manager Peter Blows, a regular first responder to the range, said the spike was due to more people visiting the national park.

"We just seem to be getting more and more calls down there, but I think that's to do with the number of people now that are discovering our lovely area," he said.

"Most people we've rescued or all of them have had all the gear … just if it gets too hot, they are down a little bit on water."

At work on the cliffs of Dyurrite/Mt Arapiles. (Supplied: SES)

Australia's peak body for bushwalking said the popularisation of wilderness hiking on social media had contributed to a rise in rescues across some of the country's top hiking trails.

"Bushwalking has become quite popular, especially in the social media groups where people get together casually and somebody says, 'Let's go to such and such an area' and then they turn up and shoot off for a walk," said Bushwalking Australia president Jeff McDonell.

"That's an issue for us because often the leaders aren't trained, and they may not have the navigation skills, and people are getting lost.

"Unfortunately, [rescues] have increased because of that."

Jeff McDonell says inexperience and lack of preparation can contribute to emergencies. (Supplied)

Inexperience to blame

Mr McDonell said while even experienced hikers could have accidents, rescues were often due to inexperience and lack of preparation.

"Bushwalking clubs are very well organised, they have trained leaders, they have first aid, they stick to the rules … never walk alone, always walk with groups, take a personal locator beacon (PLB), and if the weather turns bad, turn back," he said.

"We've got an area, Lederderg Gorge, which is only about an hour from Melbourne, and the SES have had to do several rescues recently.

"They've rescued a group of 25 people who went for a day walk and got lost, didn't have any light and got lost in the dark."

Some state parks now lend out personal locator beacons. (Supplied: SES)

In July, two hikers were rescued from the Larapinta Trail in the Northern Territory in one week, while last month in Tasmania, police found the body of a missing hiker in Mount Field National Park.

Mr McDonell said in NSW, hikers on Mt Kosciusko and in the Blue Mountains could borrow PLBs for the duration of their walks.

He said that initiative could be expanded more widely.

"I think there's a role for the national parks to take a more proactive role," he said.

"In NSW, parks are loaning out PLBs for free, and we were looking at that in Victoria."

title: Ward crowding amplifies trauma for mothers whose babies 'gone too soon'
text:
Amy Malan lost her first baby after reporting decreased fetal movements multiple times within three weeks to different medical professionals.

"I feel like that was her voice and her voice was taken away from me and she was trying to tell me she was ready to come," Ms Malan said.

"Those weeks were really vital in her care and if we saw the same person, perhaps something could have been done."

Ms Malan was one of several women who spoke at a recent forum in Darwin about the importance of seeing the same midwives or doctors, known as continuity of care.

Amy Malan has become an advocate for continuity of care after losing her daughter Georgie. (ABC News: Felicity James)

The event was organised by local mothers who have formed the group Our Birth, Our Voice, to inform the NT and federal governments about gaps in the maternal health system.

Staffing shortages at an under-resourced Royal Darwin Hospital and a lack of birthing options, including private obstetric care after the recent closure of Darwin's private maternity ward, were among the issues raised.

"The message to the government is that we're here to stay," organiser Sophia Scaturchio said.

"This is not going to be an issue that we pick up today and is gone tomorrow.

" I think the chorus of voices is getting louder and louder and louder. "

Roza Arkam-Lovasi holding her second baby, who was born earlier this year. (ABC News: Felicity James)

Others, including Roza Arkam-Lovasi, spoke about the need for a safe space for mothers and families to grieve at the hospital following the trauma of losing a baby.

"A space to be with their babies, gone too soon, and not surrounded by babies crying when theirs is silent, a space where a support person can stay for the entire duration of a hospital stay," Ms Arkam-Lovasi said.

"The heartbreak of losing a baby is immeasurable.

" The trauma of being on the maternity ward with live babies is trauma that will stay with me forever. "

Ms Arkam-Lovasi said everyone deserved the same continuity of care she received through a private midwifery program, which ensured she had the same midwife throughout her pregnancy and traumatic birth.

The forum highlighted gaps in the NT's maternity care system, with advocates calling for more investment in health. (ABC News: Felicity James)

"Although we have endured life's greatest loss, I hope that my story can help others, to feel seen, to feel heard," Ms Arkam-Lovasi said.

"To spark conversations that lead to change for lost families and maternity continuity of care in Darwin."

Tessa Czislowski has spoken publicly several times about being left to labour for hours in a public tea room at the Royal Darwin Hospital because of a shortage of beds.

Loading...

"I have obviously got Millie and she was born ultimately safely, some women aren't that lucky and it shouldn't be about luck," she said.

"The issues that we're hearing about at Royal Darwin Hospital have been there for a long time.

"It's come about as a chronic under resourcing over consecutive governments both at a territory and federal level."

Families are calling for bipartisan support to properly fund maternal services at Royal Darwin Hospital. (ABC News: Felicity James)

Karine Foulkes and her husband, who works with the Defence Department, said they would be leaving Darwin in less than two weeks to seek mental health support and birth options interstate.

The couple lost their daughter Frankie to a condition called spinal muscular atrophy type 1, after what Ms Foulkes described as an ongoing dismissal of symptoms after birth.

"I wasn't listened to on multiple occasions by doctors, by everyone, midwives, everyone, the whole system failed Frankie," Ms Foulkes said.

She also spoke about a lack of support for grieving mothers.

Karine Foulkes is leaving Darwin for better maternity and mental health care options. (ABC News: Felicity James)

"I was locked up at the Royal Darwin Hospital under the Mental Health Act because I was grieving, wasn't given a space," she said.

" There was no support whatsoever for my grief. "

If you or someone you know needs help: Red Nose (grief and loss 24/7 support) on 1300 308 307 Pregnancy, Birth and Baby (advice from maternal child health nurses) on 1800 882 436 PANDA (Perinatal Anxiety and Depression Australia) on 1300 726 306 Bears of Hope (infant loss support) on 1300 114 673

Representatives from both levels of government and NT Health chief executive Chris Hosking attended the forum.

Mr Hosking said he found the stories at the forum "harrowing" to listen to and would be meeting with his team to discuss how the feedback could be integrated into models of care.

"Simply giving the territory the equivalent of the average of the other states and territories, would add $200 million dollars a year to the NT's operating budget and make an enormous difference to our ability to deliver healthcare," he said.

He said the Northern Territory health system had been underfunded for more than a decade.

NT Health chief executive Chris Hosking said more federal funding was required to offer improved maternal services. (ABC News: Felicity James)

"The reality is the territory's going to need a new major tertiary hospital fairly soon, we've started our planning processes for that," Mr Hosking said.

"That's something that will only ever be achieved if we have strong support from the Commonwealth."

Federal Member for Solomon Luke Gosling said the government was awaiting a proposal for additional health funding from the NT government after an initial request from NT Health Minister Steve Edgington.

Women across the NT are calling for improved access to maternity services. (ABC News: Felicity James)

"I understand [federal Health Minister Mark] Butler has responded to Minister Edgington’s initial request advising that our government would be more likely to consider a detailed proposal in line with funding commitments made to NSW and Tasmania in response to withdrawal of maternity services in those jurisdictions," he said in the statement.

"Mr Butler is waiting on that proposal."

title: Kerr scores for Chelsea as manager says Matildas star is gaining confidence
text:
Sam Kerr is back among the goals — and Chelsea boss Sonia Bompastor believes her typical quality finish in the Women's Super League was just the boost of confidence the great striker needs on the comeback trail.

The Matildas captain has had a lean time in front of goal since her return in mid-September. She had netted on her return from injury against Aston Villa but then failed to score in eight games for club and country while mainly getting late cameo appearances off the bench.

That super-sub role remained on Sunday morning (AEST) when Kerr was brought on at Stamford Bridge for the last quarter of an hour against London City Lionesses, replacing fellow Matilda Ellie Carpenter, who had earlier scored her first goal for the club to put them ahead.

Kerr had a bright spell of nearly 20 minutes but again without a goal until the 94th, when the ball fell kindly to her off a defender and, quick as flash, she directed a superbly controlled chip from an unpromising angle over the retreating goalkeeper to seal the 2-0 win.

Her first goal at Stamford Bridge in nearly two years thrilled Kerr but perhaps enthused the club's French manager equally.

"I'm really pleased for Sam, she's been building up her minutes," Bompastor said.

"She was able to play more minutes with the national team, and she's getting back to a good level.

"She came in and made an impact on the game. She got a crucial goal for the team and her goal meant the game was over, even if it was in added time.

"It was nice for her, for her confidence and also for the team. Hopefully, we'll see Sam taking even more steps to get closer to her best level."

It was a big afternoon for Carpenter, too, who not only scored her first goal since her move from French giants Lyonnes but also thrived as the player of the match in a new wing-back rather than full-back role.

The change of shape meant their other right-back, Lucy Bronze, worked behind Carpenter, and the pair teamed up seamlessly to provide more of a threat down the flank, with the Aussie scoring after just 5 minutes.

"It was good. Both of them had good performances. I think they made a big impact on the game," Bompastor said of Carpenter and star England international Bronze.

"Ellie also had a really good performance. She was able to score a really important and early goal in the game."

Champions Chelsea are one point clear of Manchester City, while Manchester United also kept close, just a further point behind after they won 3-2 at Dario Vidosic's Brighton on Sunday.

Elisabeth Terland fired United ahead and Jess Park made it two after the break, but the Seagulls threatened a comeback when Fran Kirby struck.

Park then provided the assist for Lisa Naalsund in the 89th minute and United held on after Kiko Seike scored in stoppage time as Brighton, now seventh, slipped to a third straight defeat.

Tottenham are fourth after beating struggling Liverpool 2-1 with a Beth England winner, while Matildas Caitlin Foord and Steph Catley both impressed in Arsenal's 4-1 win at Leicester, where Stina Blackstenius scored twice.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Aussie Birrell loses Chennai Open final but earns award for sporting gesture
text:
A weary Kimberly Birrell has missed out on winning her maiden WTA title after losing the Chennai Open final — but the Australian earned the consolation of a special sportsmanship award for her selfless behaviour at the Indian tournament.

Gold Coast player Birrell was defeated 6-4, 6-3 by rising Indonesian player Janice Tjen in the final — a bitter disappointment as it was her second defeat in a championship match in Asia after also losing the Osaka final last year.

But seventh seed Birrell clearly was not at her sharpest after battling through an exhausting semifinal 24 hours earlier against Taiwan's Joanna Garland, in which the courageous Australian battled back from 5-0 down in the final set and saved five match points on the way to victory in 3 hours, 24 minutes.

Still, it was not just Birrell's never-say-die performance in the longest match of her career that caught the admiration of organisers so much as her admirable concern for beaten opponent Garland, who struggled with the effects of cramp and injury when on the verge of victory.

At one point, slumping with illness at the back of the court, Garland needed medical treatment, leaving the Aussie showing concern for her condition.

Then, once Birrell finally prevailed, she was more interested in hugging and consoling her vanquished opponent than revelling in one of the key breakthrough moments in her career.

"She's a great player and a great person too — we have a friendship off the court and you have to put that aside," Birrell said of Garland.

"When your opponent and a friend is struggling like that, it's really hard to concentrate and to focus. That was not fun at all, the last few games."

Ultimately, Birrell ended in tears herself, after then being presented with the tournament's Margaret Amritraj Fairplay Award for her display of sportsmanship.

The award is named in honour of the mother of Indian tennis great Vijay Amritraj, who told Birrell: "This is named after my mum for fair play, and I thought this match was truly one of those matches."

The final, though, again proved too much for the 27-year-old Birrell as she went down to fourth seed Tjen, getting her serve broken five times in all during the 2-hour duel.

The disappointment for world number 117 Birrell was tempered by how her run to the final would take her back into the world's top 100 this week at number 94.

The top Australian woman in the rankings back at the start of the year, she had dropped to number five, but will rise one place after her big week.

Meanwhile, in the Hong Kong Open final, young Canadian star Victoria Mboko managed to achieve what had just eluded another rising teen, Australian Maya Joint, in the semifinal as she overcame Spain's Cristina Bucsa for a 7-5, 6-7 (9-11), 6-2 triumph.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Fears for health funding ahead of Tasmania's state budget this week
text:
With an interim state budget to be handed down on Thursday, a peak health body fears Tasmania's public health system won't receive enough support to address ballooning demand.

Government policies to rein in spending — such as staff vacancy controls and efficiency measures — are already affecting service delivery, according to the Australian Medical Association (AMA).

AMA Tasmania president Dr Michael Lumsden-Steel said staff were "delaying decisions about anything that might cost money".

Dr Michael Lumsden-Steel says long-term solutions are needed. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

While Dr Lumsden-Steel said this budget was "critical" for health, he had little hope of it having anything other than short-term supports — or it may even introduce cuts — after Treasurer Eric Abetz foreshadowed a focus on reducing spending.

Dr Lumsden-Steel said funding problems were not unique to Tasmania's health system.

"We've got each state with massive budget problems, we're seeing each state having massive health budget and healthcare delivery problems," he said.

"We can't do it with the resources we've got at the moment."

The AMA says a "command and control structure" is running health care in Tasmania. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Health budget blows out by $400m

Treasury's Preliminary Outcomes Report in August showed a net operating balance of $1.2 billion in the 2024-25 financial year, with net debt reaching $5.04 billion.

The main blowouts have been in the Health Department, with a $400 million overspend largely on staff, including locums.

Mr Abetz said the report showed improvements "while continuing to face fiscal challenges".

"A comprehensive program of works, including with the Efficiency and Productivity Unit, will support our responsible, considered and measured management of every single taxpayer dollar," Mr Abetz said when releasing the report.

Treasury's Pre-election Financial Outlook, released in June, warned that Tasmania's debt was headed for $13 billion by 2027-28, and called for "immediate and sustained" corrective action.

Sarah Lovell says the government needs to "spend their money better". (ABC News: Owain Stia James)

Labor's health spokesperson, Sarah Lovell, said the government needed to look at the best way to spend the health budget.

"It doesn't mean they need to necessarily spend more in health, but they need to spend their money better. We need to be delivering better outcomes," Ms Lovell said.

Dr Lumsden-Steel said he wanted to see long-term solutions and a more strategic budget that considered hospitals' demand.

"When the health department gets a budget, that budget is not based on what the health department needs, it's purely based on what the government can afford," Dr Lumsden-Steel said.

"What we're seeing at the moment is a command and control structure that is running health care.

" We're seeing [government] departments running hospitals, not hospitals running hospitals with the support of [government] departments. "

Health minister says more federal funding needed

Three months into her role as health minister, Bridget Archer is under pressure to address long ambulance wait times and a growing elective surgery waitlist, which is currently at 9,275 — a 14 per cent increase in the past 12 months.

Loading...

A wage dispute with public sector unions, including the Health and Community Services Union, is also heating up.

Asked on ABC Radio Hobart about potential cuts to health services, Ms Archer said the public sector generally had grown significantly since the COVID-19 pandemic.

"What we'd be looking to do is to look to what some of those [public service] settings looked like before the pandemic," she said.

"But, certainly, there will be no impact on those frontline services that Tasmanians need."

In relation to health funding, Ms Archer has called on the federal government to do more, saying Tasmania would be more than $670 million worse off under a proposed public hospital agreement with the states.

"The federal government is asking Tasmania, and asking all of the states, to reduce their health demand, but they are not providing us with the resources that we need, or the tools that we need, to reduce the demand in the first place," Ms Archer said.

The federal government, which has recently brought in bulk-billing incentives, said it was already providing the state government more than enough.

title: WA premier, treasurer head east as fight for WA's GST share heats up
text:
The state government has defended spending $1 million on an advertising campaign about Western Australia’s GST deal, as the fight to protect the state’s carve-up of the distribution ramps up.

It comes as Premier Roger Cook and Treasurer Rita Saffioti prepare to meet with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Canberra on Monday, with the GST deal and looming federal environment law reforms expected to be on the list of discussion points.

The campaign, called "WA's GST is working for Australia", will launch later this week, with advertisements set to run in eastern states newspapers, on billboards in Canberra, on radio and online.

The state government has spent $1 million on an advertising campaign about WA's GST deal. (Supplied)

"This is a real fight to make sure that WA keeps the deal that was struck in 2018," Ms Saffioti said on Sunday, ahead of her trip to Canberra.

"I would say every time we've been to the other states … it's constantly thrown in our face, the GST deal, and [by] economic commentators … it's now got to the public over east.

"So we have a job to inform people that a good GST deal for WA is good for the nation.

"We need to make sure that they understand that tearing up or changing the GST deal to penalise WA would impact national economic growth and national jobs."

Cash splash 'worth it': Treasurer

Reforms to the GST distribution by the Morrison government in 2018 mean WA keeps at least 75 cents for every dollar of GST revenue.

WA GST deal under review Western Australia's GST deal, expected to cost the Commonwealth $60 billion by 2029, will form part of a review by the Australian Productivity Commission.

In September, Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers released the terms of reference for the Australian Productivity Commission's review into those reforms, a review mandated by law.

In response, Ms Saffioti established a GST "fairness fighter" team within the Department of Treasury to lead the State's response to the review.

According to the government and the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry, without the 2018 deal, WA would receive 18 per cent of its population share for 2025-26, which they calculated as $6 billion less.

Ms Saffioti says WA would be worse off without the 2018 GST deal. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"This is a fight worth $6.5 billion this year," Ms Saffioti said on Sunday.

" So we believe spending $1 million to educate over in the eastern states is worth it because we're trying to prevent $6.5 billion being ripped off WA. "

Point of contention

The GST deal has been a point of contention between states and territories since they were changed in 2018.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese as good as promised WA's deal would not change during the election campaign, going as far as signing that statement on a reporters arm.

But the review has stoked new fears the deal is at risk.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese wrote and signed No Change To WA GST on a reporters arm during the federal election campaign. (AAP: Richard Wainwright)

"While Anthony Albanese and the Federal Government have backed WA and the current GST deal, we know east coast states are trying to tear down the GST floor and reduce WA's GST share even further," a "GST Fact Sheet" provided by the WA government as part of the advertising campaign stated.

"It's just not fair and Western Australia can't sit on the sidelines."

Part of the government's argument is that the current GST share received by WA is invested into economic infrastructure that drives the nation's economy.

The GST deal has been a point of contention between states and territories since the rules were changed in 2018. (ABC News: Sharon Gordon)

"Without this GST deal that was struck in 2018 we wouldn't be in a position to support economic growth, to build the roads, to build the ports, to make sure we get the energy and water infrastructure to support new projects," Ms Saffioti said on Sunday.

"That GST deal is fundamental to WA's economic growth and national economic growth.

"Even with the GST deal we are contributing $2.5 billion to other states … and that's just in GST.

"They [people outside of WA] all think that somehow, they're not getting anything out of WA."

Environmental reforms on the agenda

Mr Cook and Ms Saffioti also plan to meet with Federal Environment Minister Murray Watt to discuss once-in-a-generation reforms to Australia's environment laws, introduced to parliament last week.

Murray Watt will meet with Roger Cook and Rita Saffioti in Canberra this week. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

Ms Saffioti said they would be looking to ensure "industry continues to be involved".

"It's making sure there's clarity … it's like all legislation, so you got the concept and then you've got the details and making sure that the details don't have any undesired consequences or consequences that couldn't be predicted," she said.

title: Possible storms and showers forecast for south-east Queensland as weather cools
text:
Evening showers and a possible storm are forecast for south-east Queensland after a weekend of wild weather, while the state's west will be significantly cooler than average.

Weather bureau senior meteorologist Angus Hines said inland areas between Brisbane and the Capricornia region still faced the chance of a few late showers or an isolated storm on Monday after a partly cloudy day.

"If you're right down at the coastline, the risk of rainfall looks pretty slim," he said.

The outlook is "a wholesale change in conditions" from the severe thunderstorms that threatened the state on Saturday.

"On Monday across the east coast, generally bright weather and lots of sunshine," Mr Hines said.

"The large and giant hailstones that we've seen — we're unlikely to see a repeat of that.

"The high-end severe weather is not likely to be replicated.

"It's big changes in the atmosphere across Queensland, not just at the surface level but even higher up in the atmosphere."

Some residents from the Scenic Rim and Gold Coast received hail overnight. (Supplied: Carmel Barnfield)

Residents in Tamborine Mountain, as well as in northern Gold Coast suburbs including Pacific Pines and Maudsland, received hailstones up to 5 centimetres in diameter overnight.

Cooler in the west as rain arrives

Mr Hines said temperatures across western parts of the state could be up to 12 degrees Celsius below average on Monday.

"We are going to see a band of rain and a change to much cooler temperatures move into western parts of the state," he said.

"That's going to mean some spots in the low or mid 20s.

"Typically at this time of year [it's] around 35 to 38 degrees out in the far west.

Two dogs cool off in a creek in Rockhampton. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

"We're looking at fairly extensive wet weather from the far south-west around Birdsville and channel country up to the north-west.

"Probably not particularly heavy rain for most of these areas, just light to moderate falls, but fairly extensive wet weather with a lot of places getting at least a small drop of rain."

Coastal showers on Tuesday

The bureau predicts the band of wet weather will push towards the coast on Tuesday.

"Most people won't get that much, they're not huge rainfall totals," Mr Hines said.

Skies were beginning to clear at Maroochydore this morning. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Josh Dye)

"The temperature change won't be as dramatic … but a few degrees cooler for some coastal spots from around Wednesday onwards.

"Even though it might be a few degrees cooler, [it's] generally looking to be quite dry across the state."

The rest of the week is forecast to be mostly sunny in the south-east.

A severe heatwave in the Far North will gradually ease as the week progresses.

title: Legal errors raise questions over AI use in Victorian courtrooms
text:
An increasing number of court cases are being disrupted by the use of artificial intelligence, which is providing false case citations.

In the past year in Victoria, one solicitor's practising conditions were changed and a law firm was ordered to pay costs in another matter, after using AI to produce court documents, which returned errors.

Family law specialist Caroline Counsel, who is also chair of family law at the Victorian Law Institute, told the Mornings program on ABC Radio that AI was making its way into courtrooms in Victoria, with some problematic results.

"Unfortunately, people sort of think AI is the genie that's going to solve all the problems, but in actual fact it's like a really keen intern that wants to please," she said.

"So, if you ask it something and don't ask how it got to that conclusion, it could spit out what they call hallucinations — something that looks like a case, smells like a case and might even have a judge's name in it that's familiar to you — but the rest of it is just made up."

Caroline Counsel says AI is making its way into courtrooms. (Supplied: Caroline Counsel Family Lawyers)

AI has grabbed national headlines recently, with the ABC revealing more than a dozen universities in Australia were using AI to catch out students believed to be using AI in assessments, and getting it wrong.

The ABC has also highlighted issues facing Australian Community Media through its use of Google's Gemini model in regional newsrooms, with some staff raising concerns about the legal advice being offered by the AI system.

The law industry's watchdog, the Victorian Legal Services Board and Commissioner, has been forced to call out the misuse of AI tools such as generative AI — which creates content in response to user prompts — to prepare court documents.

Fabrications and hallucinations

Federal Court documents show in August last year, solicitor Mr Dayal — a pseudonym given to him by the court — submitted a list and summary of legal authorities that did not exist and admitted not checking either for accuracy.

In that case, Mr Dayal told the court he would "take the lessons learned to heart and will not commit any such further breach of professional standards in the future".

Mr Dayal was referred by the court to the industry's watchdog for a review of his conduct.

In August this year, the Victorian Legal Services Board varied Mr Dayal's practising certificate so he could no longer practise as a principal lawyer or handle trust money, and required him to undertake supervised legal practice for a period of two years.

And the case of Mr Dayal was not the only one.

The legal industry is struggling with the use of AI in court. (ABC Graphics: Lindsay Dunbar)

In July this year, Federal Court judge Bernard Murphy found it was not appropriate to refer a law firm to the Victorian Legal Services Board after an "inexperienced junior solicitor" used AI to prepare citations in legal documents for a native title claim.

That case found the junior solicitor had used Google Scholar's search tool to produce a list of citations, but then, when she attempted to replicate her search methods, Google Scholar returned different results.

Court documents show the junior solicitor apologised to the parties and to the court for her error, and the law firm she worked for was ordered to pay costs.

Justice Murphy said it was likely that the false document citations came from using generative AI, which had the capacity to "fabricate" or "hallucinate" information.

Legal bodies are questioning the role of AI in the profession. (Unsplash: Sasun Bughdaryan/License)

Putting the genie back in the bottle

In its latest risk outlook, the Office of the Victorian Legal Services Board and Commissioner identified the improper use of AI as a key risk.

"Unlike a professionally trained lawyer, AI can't exercise superior judgement or provide ethical and confidential services," a spokesperson said.

The Supreme Court of Victoria and County Court of Victoria have established guidelines on the use of AI by lawyers, while the Victorian Legal Services Board has joined its counterparts in Western Australia and New South Wales to publish a statement on the use of AI in Australia's legal practice.

Ms Counsel said the courts "were trying to put the genie back in the bottle" as they grappled with lawyers using AI technology to prepare court documents.

"It's basically saying, 'Hey, look, you can't just use this randomly, and you can't generate footnotes or citations because we know that AI has this capacity to hallucinate, and you can't actually generate witness statements affidavits using AI,'" Ms Counsel said.

The board said cases where lawyers had misled the court by tendering false citations generated by AI were increasingly the focus of regulators.

It said if the misuse of AI was proven, it might take disciplinary action by reprimanding the lawyer or ordering further education.

The board said it would consider prosecuting a matter before the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal if the misuse amounted to professional misconduct.

title: 'Families in tears' as daycare drought keeps workers out of jobs
text:
Johanna Murphy spent a decade honing her specialist skills as a sports physiotherapist, but a childcare drought in her south-western New South Wales town means she can only work one day per week.

The mum of three is currently unable to take new patients and said this had a profound flow-on effect on the entire town.

"The perfect example would be: you wake up one morning and you can't move your head because your neck’s locked up. If you can't get in to see the physio to begin treatment, you can't sit at your desk because it's too sore," Ms Murphy said.

"People then can't do their job and if they're not doing their work, their colleagues take the load or the work just doesn't get done.

" I think if you asked everyone in town, they would be able to track an issue with access back to someone not being able to access childcare. "

Johanna Murphy only works one day per week in her private physiotherapy practice because she cannot get child care. (Supplied: Johanna Murphy)

Residents leaving, jobs unfilled

The Edward River Council has collated data that shows 69 per cent of local children currently do not have access to a childcare place, with waitlists for local services exceeding 300 families.

The situation was further exacerbated in July when a local centre closed suddenly due to compliance issues, leaving nearly 30 families without care.

Mayor Ashley Hall said the council was working with an early education provider to establish a new 110-place daycare centre, but conceded it was still years away.

There is a shortage of daycare services in Deniliquin. (Supplied: River Region Early Education)

"It's the number one advocacy role that council are playing at the moment," Cr Hall said.

"We've got tremendous support from our community, but we need outside help, particularly for capital funding from the state and federal government."

River Region Early Education provides daycare services in Deniliquin and surrounding rural communities.

General manager Felicity Michael said families were leaving the region and essential worker roles were hard to fill because of the shortage.

Felicity Michael says essential workers are not coming to the region due to a lack of child care. (Supplied: Felicity Michael)

"We know of two teachers who have had to leave teaching positions in Deniliquin due to a lack of care for their children, and nurses unable to take up positions at the hospital due to the lack of childcare," she said.

Ms Michael said data from the Australian Early Development Census also highlighted a concerning trend.

"It is impacting the development of children, with more children in Deniliquin being developmentally vulnerable in two or more domains than the NSW or national average," she said.

"Children who are able to access early childhood education and care are more likely to be able to access early intervention [that will] set them up for a bright future. The lack of childcare is limiting these children's access to this vital early intervention."

The NSW Department of Education says the state government will deliver a new pre-school at Deniliquin South Public School by 2027. (Supplied: River Region Early Education)

A town on tenterhooks

Edward River Council had been in discussions with the NSW Education Department on establishing a temporary daycare centre at a local public school, but the proposal has stalled.

In a statement, a spokesperson said the department was working with local stakeholders to identify a solution for the short term.

They said the state government would deliver five new pre-schools in the wider Riverina region by 2027, including one at Deniliquin South Public School.

For now, though, Johanna Murphy said tensions were running high in town.

"My receptionist at work is getting some pretty unhappy clients calling who are trying to get in to see a physio and can't," she said.

"The poor admin staff at the childcare centres … there are people calling every single day to check in again, 'Am I further up the waitlist, am I any closer to getting childcare?' They’re getting families in tears in their waiting room.

"It is dire straits in Deniliquin and we need a solution as soon as possible."

title: Live: Optus staff took hours to escalate discovery of deaths in triple-0 failure
text:
A press conference originally convened to discuss the inquiry into the Optus triple-0 outage has veered into questions about net zero by 2050 after that decision from the Nationals at the weekend.

WA Liberal Dean Smith says the Coalition must be focused on holding Labor to account for high energy prices, which he says is making life tough for families and businesses.

(ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

But Smith has welcomed the National party for providing clarity on their net zero position.

"Their position will help inform our position. But I'm sure the National Party is very, very, very aware that the Liberal Party will come with its own position, informed by its own priorities and considerations," Smith says.

Liberal senator Sarah Henderson has jumped in off the back off Smith to say that she hopes her colleagues turn their back entirely on net zero.

"I believe that we will get a position where we will work together to reject Labor's net zero laws," Henderson says. "These policies are not working. Australians can see it. The National Party have called this out.

"We are very concerned to ensure that we continue to reduce emissions. But we are not going to allow Australians to pay the highest price," she says.

Henderson says she hopes the Liberals reach a position "as soon as possible" and that deliberations won't continue for much longer.

title: Australia news LIVE: Ley’s leadership in peril as senior Liberals move to dump net zero; Optus chair stands by CEO after Triple Zero outage
text:
Earlier this year, this masthead’s Bidding Blind investigation revealed that prospective home buyers are being frequently misled by unrealistic price guides.

The project analysed more than 36,000 property sales in Melbourne and Sydney across 18 months and found that more than half of homes put up for auction in Australia’s two largest cities sold above the top end of the price guide (even when allowing for 10 per cent wriggle room in Sydney).

A special investigation of 26,000 auctions reveals just how badly Melbourne’s property guide system misleads buyers. Credit: Mark Stehle

One of the ways agents get away with underquoting is by encouraging homeowners to allow them to advertise their properties at a lower price than they would be prepared to sell for, the investigation found.

“The argument [from the agent] was, ‘You’ve got to create competition in the marketplace. If we go to auction, we would need to list for less so the auctioneer can build competition amongst the bidders,’” said Melbourne woman Maree.

We’re looking to speak to people who have recently sold a home about their experience of underquoting and price guides. You can contact journalist Aisha Dow on aisha.dow@nine.com.au or fill in the survey (leaving your contact details) below.

title: Brisbane news live: Man ‘stabbed in neck with fork’; Premier promises e-bike crackdown; Beetlejuice the Musical coming to Brisbane
text:
Do not be fooled by the patches of blue sky this morning, Brisbane is in for another muggy and stormy day.

Brisbane avoided the worst of the storms this weekend and today’s storms are also expected to be less severe.

It is expected to begin raining across the city from 10am, with thunderstorms to roll in from 4pm.

The humidity level is currently at 79 per cent, making the temperature of 26 degrees feel more like 30 degrees.

While it is hot and humid, at least it’s not a repeat of last Monday when Brisbane sweltered through its hottest October day in 21 years.

title: Westpac boss says selling $21.4b RAMS loan book will help cut costs
text:
Westpac chief executive Anthony Miller says offloading the $21.4 billion RAMS home loan portfolio will help the bank’s long-term plan to streamline its technology and cut costs, even though the sale will reduce the bank’s market share.

As Westpac delivered a 1 per cent fall in full-year profits on Monday, it also announced it was selling the RAMS home loan portfolio to a consortium, a move that will result in Westpac losing a chunk of the mortgage market.

Westpac has about 21 per cent of the home loan market at present, but its loans are spread across three different banking systems: one for Westpac–branded loans, one for St George and regional brands such as Bank of Melbourne, and one for RAMS.

“In effect, I’ve got three small banks, three small bank cost challenges, three small bank compliance, three small bank risk challenges in managing the mortgage book,” Miller said.

The bank is undergoing a major technology project that will result in all its loans being moved onto one system, and this would have required significant spending for the RAMS loan book. Selling RAMS allowed the bank to achieve its goals faster and more efficiently, Miller said.

title: Savaged Optus boss faces claims of misleading Senate
text:
“It seems very clear that it was more important to you and to your executive team to make sure your corporate ducks were in order, that your profits will be in order, than people’s safety and transparency with government,” she said. “You didn’t give any further update... even when you knew on the Thursday night that it was worse than you had previously informed the government.” Pressed repeatedly on why he didn’t immediately provide updated information about the true number affected or deaths, Rue insisted he “wanted to provide accurate information” but admitted that his call to notify the regulator came nearly 18 hours after learning of the first fatality. Rue also conceded there were delayed welfare checks on at-risk customers as engineers scrambled to manually identify failed emergency calls. In his opening statement, Rue announced that Optus would add 300 people to its Australian call centres focused on Triple Zero customers and would on-shore its network operations from offshore contractors, in response to the catastrophic network failure.

He said Optus accepted full responsibility for the failures and said he “regretted reforms were not embedded earlier to prevent them”. Loading “We are all deeply sorry, the tragic deaths of people during this outage will stay with us as individuals and as a company, as we investigate and build on our response while progressing a sweeping transformation of Optus,” he said. “We will add around 300 people to our Australian call centres focused on Triple Zero and vulnerable customers, including our specialist care teams helping customers in rural areas, elderly customers or those with serious medical conditions. “In May this year, the board approved a management proposal to take back in-house network activities currently performed by Nokia, both onshore and offshore. At the time, the aim was to transition this work progressively to May 2027, but I have now asked the networks team to accelerate the move.

“In addition to the on-shoring activities in call centres and networks, we are also recruiting 150 people to be part of a new Process Centre of Excellence in Australia, to accelerate the transformation and overall procedures across the business.” Loading Rue pushed back on calls for his resignation that have come from across the political spectrum. “I firmly believe that another change of leader at this time is not what Optus needs or what our customers need. The disruption and uncertainty could actually set back the transformation underway and create further risks,” he said. Optus chair John Arthur backed his chief executive, but promised future consequences for staff responsible for the Triple Zero outage.

“That’s his job. Now, he’s partway through this job and I’m expecting him to finish it,” Arthur said. “Because I never in my life want to be in the position I’m in today where I have to answer these sorts of questions about a company I’m associated with.” He said once an internal Optus review, a review by the regulator, and the Senate inquiry were finalised, there would be consequences for both junior and senior staff. “I can assure you that there will be [accountabilities] when the dust settles. And what I mean by that is that when we have all of the facts… the board will deal with accountabilities.” The crisis stemmed from a botched firewall upgrade at Regency Park exchange in South Australia, where technicians failed to redirect traffic before locking down a critical “session border gateway”, according to Optus’ submission to the inquiry. Optus’ Paul O’Sullivan, former chairman, John Arthur, chairman, and Stephen Rue, CEO, at the Triple Zero service outage hearing at Parliament House in Canberra on Monday. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen

The submission reveals Nokia contractors used an outdated procedure document and incorrectly rated the change as “zero risk”, bypassing crucial engineering reviews. It states that Nokia personnel selected an “outdated Method of Procedure (MOP) document” for the change. This outdated document “did not include making changes... to ‘offload’ traffic from the Session Border Gateway” before applying the lock. Loading The work was also brought forward 24 hours without proper authorisation. Automated alarms for general call failures were generated within minutes of the outage starting. Those alerts, at 12.20am on September 18, were dismissed as routine maintenance activity, while five customer calls reporting Triple Zero failures between 10.13am and 2.57pm went unescalated – a “serious process issue” that Optus acknowledged was unacceptable.

The outage wasn’t identified until 1.17pm when South Australian Ambulance Service called Optus directly. Services were restored by 2.34pm, but the damage was done. Efforts to conduct welfare checks on affected customers were then delayed because the technical fault meant that standard Call Detail Records (CDRs) “showed no unsuccessful calls”. Engineers had to devise new methods to identify affected customers, with the first 100 identified by 7.50pm – more than five hours after services were restored. A further 524 customers were identified the next morning, followed by seven more days later. Welfare checks didn’t commence until 8.34pm on September 18, with Optus learning of the first fatality at 8.43pm. By Friday afternoon, three deaths had been reported, rising to four by Saturday. The company has appointed former Sydney Water chief executive Dr Kerry Schott to lead an independent review, and engaged consulting firm Kearney to oversee network management improvements. The inquiry continues.

title: Melbourne Cup 2025
text:
The Melbourne Cup is almost upon us, and this is the easiest and best way to organise your home, party or office sweep. Enter the player names, get your picks and watch the race. Easy.

November 1, 2025
